Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Amanda was clearly excited about the content of the course, which was nice to see. However, her interactions with the students were sometimes condescending and did make motivate me to engage with the material

Instructor: Leah Elizabeth Butler  Leah was a great TA, very attentive and responsive to student responses. She is very knowledgable about the material and gave great feedback. One of the best TAs I've had!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 4: This course seemed geared more toward undergraduates in pace and material covered. It was a great overview of various concepts in sustainable design but I can't say I learned too many new things. That being said, I can see how undergrads would enjoy this course and get a lot out of it because the way we learn to see problems really opens up your thoughts.

This class could have been a lot better-- Paul Anastas is incredible, super smart and a great lecturer. But, he sometimes seemed really distracted and we just covered the very very basics of green engineering, without getting into the specifics of anything. This class has the huge potential to be one of the best classes at FES, but it just went too slow sometimes and we wasted too much time on certain things, e.g.: the in class exercises were pretty pointless

This could be a great class, but because of the way it's set up, it's not. On the first day, more than 50 students packed into Kroon 321. It was announced that all engineering undergrads would be allowed to stay. The class was whittled down to 35 or 40, still pretty big, oftentimes there were not enough seats or desks in the room for everyone. This was way below my expectation for graduate school. I did not come to Yale to work with 19 and 20 year olds who have zero work experience. It was ridiculous. It seems strange to lump together three different schools -- FES, Engineering, and Environmental Engineering -- into one big class, especially when the topic is so popular; there should be two sessions for this, one for grad level and another for undergrad.

Question 2: The final project was very useful in helping me apply the things I learned in the course to a real-life situation, but I found the problem sets to be rote and not helpful at all. I honestly felt like I was doing a high school homework assignment.Question 4: I thought that the course tried to cover a bit too much ground in a semester. I wish it cut out a few topics and dove more deeply into others.Question 13: I really liked the concept of the course and very much enjoyed exploring most of the topics, but the fact that there were so many undergrads made it tough to cater to everyone's knowledge base. Many of the sessions were total repeats of stuff I already knew, while others were entirely new to me. I think if it were limited to masters students only it would be a much better class for those students.

This course did not feel like it should be part of graduate school. The concepts were repetitive and too surface level.I was also very frustrated with the final project. I strongly believe that students in the US should not design products for people in other countries without better understanding the conditions and circumstances in that country. The course taught that ethnography and lengthy observation were key principles for design, but this was not part of the assignment. Also, the insistence on designing something that had never been created or thought of seemed silly, given that so many problems arise because of the way products are implemented, and given that we do not have expertise in these areas.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Most of the in-class exercises were great. I liked the hands-on aspect of the course, but it also felt very elementary.
The lectures with Paul and Julie
the projects were great
The project which involved real time implementation of concepts learnt in class.
The design project was a great learning experience.
Encourages you to think innovatively !
Introduction to a variety of design and green engineering concepts in a short period of time. The opportunity to complete a design project.
Final design challenge and hands-on exercises.
Paul Anastas was a great instructor. His experience and enthusiasm always shine through and it was great to have him.

- Relevance of key sustainable design concepts to my post-academic career- The final project, with some tweaks - I felt there needed to be much more direction from the professor and TAs, especially since they had info available early on that for some reason we weren't able to access until halfway through the semester
Getting to know the CEID and new methods for evaluating alternatives.
Biomimicry

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More complexity in the course material. I would have liked spending more time on LCA, life cycle costing, MCDA, etc... the quantitative things that matter in assessing feasibility of a project.
The in class exercises (appropriate technology for the developing world, biomimicry, etc.) were pretty boring and just were too redundant from our reading/lectures to actually be useful.
maybe try to get into CEID and/or a real seminar room so it is more of a discussion based class

The design projects could be better organized, and to make things more equitable, all design projects should be more similar. For example, they could all focus on a product to primarily be marketed in North America, so that all groups have equal opportunity to do adequate research, including market research and testing. There was a significant difference with how much research was possible between groups that worked on, for example, the Yale wastewater treatment solution versus the Mexican coffee project.The survey on group members should be done after the final project presentations, because at least 50% of the project work was done in the last 2 weeks, and because the survey was done 2 weeks before the presentations, this was not taken into account. In addition, the types of skillsets involved in the latter tasks of the project were quite different from those required in the first few weeks, and so different teammates had more opportunities to contribute at different times.

Allowing undergrads in is a terrible idea, that should not be allowed. When nearly half the class is undergrad, that's a HUGE problem.It would have been good to get design and charrette support from Paul or some other seasoned veteran (not the TA's) for our final project. We are sort of left high and dry to figure it out, even just some design support to bring the ideas forward by an experienced professional would have been helpful.A one-pager that describes the deliverables for the final project would have helped, a brief that describes in detail what is being asked for each step. The PPT slides were not specific enough, communication was lacking, and we are not god mind readers.
Need advanced textbook
The design challenges were not entirely well matched to the goals of the design project. Allow more flexibility for interpretation of the design challenges.

I don't think it makes sense for this to be an undergrad/grad mixed class. We didn't choose our own groups and I think I got a lot less out of the course because of the group I was placed in.This course talked a lot about design but had less actual doing of design. I think it would be better if we did a lot more in-depth evaluation of different design cases and more iterative practice actually designing a lot of things. We have scientists and engineers leading the course, but I think it's missing the creativity of a designer.

- The problem sets (see my comments above)- The in-class exercises. A few of them were ok (biomimicry, bottom of the pyramid) but others were a waste of time (the chemistry one)- The course blew through the ideation process way too quickly to do it its proper justice
Maybe have a discussion section about the problem sets. A field trip to the Yale Power Plant or other local facilities woud have been interesting.
The assignments and final project should be more tailored to the lessons in class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No discussion or lab.
n/a
Very good discussion facilitation by Paul.
Yes
N/A
No lab/discussion section.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: The teaching assistants were great.
Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Amanda is a great TA. It would have been great if she had more office hours, but I understand she's busy with her own work.
Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  She was a great TA as well
Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Very helpfulApproachable
Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Very good at communication and managing of student requests. Made herself available for questions/advice frequently.

Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Amanda was enthusiastic and committed as a TA, but I found her class lecture and general interactions suggested an underlying discomfort and a lack of organization. Perhaps there was not good communication in the teaching team in general and that affected Amanda disproportionately. Or perhaps she needs to put more time into preparation. Whatever the cause, I offer this feedback because I think my impression was shared by others and therefore may be helpful in her development as an academic.

Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  This is 2013 and we're in an environmental school. Students shouldn't be forced to submit hard copies of assignments just because the TA is disorganized and doesn't know how to use the track changes function. I'm the surprised the TAs were so inept as to not be able to 'greenly design' a way to go paperless for this class.

Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  - Overall I thought Amanda did a great job of being engaged and accessible whenever we needed her. That said, I found that particularly with respect to the final project she could have done a better job of relaying information that would have been useful to us from the outset.
Instructor: Amanda Winston Lounsbury  Amanda seemed angry with the students but this didn't translate into constructive learning.
Instructor: Leah Elizabeth Butler  Leah was great, relaxed and helpful.
Instructor: Leah Elizabeth Butler  They were both very organized and brought some life into the class, great at giving feedback and coordinating class activities.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It fits well, but I wish we covered more topics at more depth
I am interested in corporate sustainability and sustainable design.
Very important subject matter.
The course helped me think broad and innovative.
I think this kind of course is very important because it looks forward and is about creating something rather than just analyzing something that has already happened.

This course will be critical in any future role I have as a product designer or, really, in any future sustainability role. It covered a ton of ground (perhaps TOO much for its own good!) and exposed me to a lot of new concepts and ways of thinking that will continue to serve me well going forward.

This course did not really provide me additional learning given that I'm familiar with these concepts, albeit on a surface level, already. It was very much a repeat in a way that was less strongly presented as in other instances. Looking back, I should not have taken this course.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: My concentration is in industrial ecology so I thought it would be helpful to take this Green Design course to learn how industrial ecology fits with the design process.
Because the project, as it promoted innovative thought process.
Interested in green design.
I was interested in Green Engineering and the Professor is well known for the field.
Learn the concepts of green engineering, and get an opportunity to engage in a design project.
To learn quantitative engineering methods for problem solving and practice with innovation and design theories and processes.
Interest
See above.
I wanted to learn from Paul Anastas and be forced to build something.
I thought it would enhance my learning.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I expected more from this class because it's cross-listed with Env'l Engineering... more in terms of quantification and such.
No, it was a bit too basic
yes - at times it seemed a bit wide ranging but they did a great job provided that
Yes, for the most part.
Kind of..Could be better..
For the most part yes.
Not quite. See question 17.

For the most part. I thought I would acquire a bit deeper technical understanding of basic engineering and chemistry concepts. I also found that the course covered a lot of things I already knew about - LCA, basics of energy and water use in green design.
No

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: My project was okay... I didn't like that half my team was usually unavailable during the first half of the semester because we are rushing to get things done in the final weeks and that's adding stress to my schedule.
It often felt like busy work
it was a great project but unfortunately (as with all group work) work gets put off until the last minute
Made me effective team player.

The group work had a lot of learning value. It was a very different type of project, because there wasn't necessarily a direct correlation between the amount of work/ time you put in and the quality of your final project, as it's very dependent on whether or not you come up with a good idea.

Working with undergrads 10 years younger than me was terrible. They are just in a completely different place, professionally academically and emotionally. I tried to be open minded about it, but this class was just ridiculous in the end because if it.
Brainstorming sessions were super-helpful
Challenge in working with different backgrounds, but great experience for future projects at Yale and in my career.

Primary advantage was having diverse personal and professional/academic experiences to bear on the design challenge.Primary disadvantage was attempting to schedule across very different graduate and undergraduate schedules.

I don't think the groups were well matched or well thought-out. There were groups of 3 with two first or second year undergrads and an MEM student. And there was a group with 2 MEMs and joint MEM/MBA and a PhD student. Some people including myself feel they missed out on a real professional-level team collaboration experience.
Advantages:- LOVED the diversity of skills and backgrounds (especially having an engineer in the group)- Liked how early on the group was formedDisadvantages:- None
Learning to work in challenging teams

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: I don't think this class is worth taking if you've had any exposure whatsoever to green chemistry, environmental policy, LCA. You're better off taking classes dedicated solely to environmental policy, design, or LCA than this taste-testing-like course.
its a class about changing how you think and create ideas, if your not into that then dont take it.

If you're interested in a discussion-heavy class with a lot of pondering over ideas, and a group project that allows for a lot of creativity and idea generation, then you would probably enjoy this class.

This could be a great class, but because of the way it's set up, it's not. On the first day, more than 50 students packed into Kroon 321. It was announced that all engineering undergrads would be allowed to stay. The class was whittled down to 35 or 40, still pretty big, oftentimes there were not enough seats or desks in the room for everyone. About half the class was undergrads. This was way below my expectation for graduate school. Working with undergrads 10 years younger than me was borderline ridiculous. They are just in a completely different place, professionally academically and emotionally, and it bogged the class down (especially the group work, which there is a lot of). I tried to be open minded about it, but this class fell way below my expectations as a result. FES is supposed to be a professional graduate school -- there should be two sessions for this class, one for grad students and another for undergrads.
Participate in class discussions
Get started early and meet regularly

If you are looking for much of the same content as the industrial ecology class but with more hands-on exercises and practical skill acquisition take this class. If you are really interested in sustainability metrics take this class in addition to the industrial ecology class(es).
Find out what the projects are and try to form a group in advance.

- More of a survey course that exposes you to a broad range of green design concepts- Great for beginners in this space, not as good for those with already deep knowledge of sustainable design- Manageable workload- Final project can be a great experience but should be worked on throughout semester, NOT at end!- Paul is very passionate and brings an incredible wealth of knowledge
Sit at the front of the room! Become a CEID member straight away and start making a prototype for your project early in the semester.
Talk to more students and hear their feedback
